Gastroenteritis.headline: Gastroenteritis — Stomach/intestinal inflammation
Gastroenteritis.summary: Vomiting and decreased appetite are common signs. Causes include dietary indiscretion, mild infections, or irritation. Most mild cases resolve with supportive care, but monitor closely.
immediateCare: Withhold food for 6–12 hours for adult dogs; allow small sips of water.
Monitor for dehydration and offer small amounts of water frequently.
If vomiting stops, give small bland meals (boiled chicken and rice) in tiny portions before resuming normal diet.
redFlags: Repeated vomiting or ongoing vomiting for >24 hours
Severe lethargy or signs of dehydration
prevention: Avoid table scraps and sudden diet changes
Keep garbage and foreign foods out of reach
Gastroenteritis.whatToTellVet: Vomiting started [duration], frequency [#], appetite [reduced/normal], any access to garbage or new food?

Foreign body.headline: Possible foreign body / obstruction
Foreign body.summary: Ingested objects can block the gastrointestinal tract and quickly become an emergency. Repeated vomiting, retching, and abdominal pain are suspicious signs.
immediateCare: Do not attempt to induce vomiting without veterinary advice.
Keep the pet calm and withhold food until evaluated.
Seek veterinary attention promptly — imaging may be needed.
redFlags: Non-productive retching (trying to vomit with nothing produced)
Repeated vomiting, abdominal pain, or distension
prevention: Supervise pets with small objects and remove swallowable items
Foreign body.whatToTellVet: Describe what (if anything) was swallowed, timeline of vomiting, behavior, and whether the pet is still passing stool.

Pancreatitis.headline: Pancreatitis — Inflammation of the pancreas
Pancreatitis.summary: Pancreatitis can cause sudden severe vomiting, abdominal pain, and lethargy. It often follows ingestion of fatty food but can occur spontaneously.
immediateCare: Seek veterinary evaluation — supportive care often requires fluids and pain control.
Do not feed and avoid giving any medications without veterinary instruction.
redFlags: Severe or repeated vomiting, abdominal pain (hunched posture)
prevention: Avoid fatty foods and table scraps
Pancreatitis.whatToTellVet: Note recent dietary changes or access to fatty foods, frequency of vomiting, and any abdominal pain or behavioral changes.

Toxin ingestion.headline: Possible toxin ingestion
Toxin ingestion.summary: Many household foods, plants, and chemicals are toxic to pets. If ingestion is suspected, rapid action is needed.
immediateCare: If you suspect poisoning, contact your veterinarian or animal poison control immediately.
Do not induce vomiting unless specifically instructed.
redFlags: Sudden onset of severe vomiting, drooling, tremors, seizures
Known access to a toxic substance
prevention: Store chemicals, medications, and toxic plants out of reach
Supervise pets around human food and trash
Toxin ingestion.whatToTellVet: Specify the substance (if known), time of exposure, amount (if known), and current symptoms.

Kidney disease.headline: Potential kidney-related illness
Kidney disease.summary: Vomiting accompanied by increased or decreased urination, changes in thirst, or lethargy may suggest kidney involvement and needs veterinary assessment.
immediateCare: Ensure access to water and monitor drinking and urination
Seek veterinary evaluation if urine changes, weakness, or repeated vomiting occur
redFlags: Marked changes in drinking or urination
Severe lethargy, collapse, or persistent vomiting
prevention: Keep pets hydrated and maintain regular wellness exams
Follow veterinarian advice on diets for at-risk animals
Kidney disease.whatToTellVet: Provide info on drinking/urination changes, any pre-existing kidney disease, and medication use.
